God bless Corporal Christie and the members of the Hamilton County community who continue to honor his memory and make sure his sacrifice will never be forgotten. üá∫üá∏

Scientists used DNA and other evidence to determine the identity of Christie's remains, finding Body X-214 was, in fact, his body. This weekend, Christie's body will be laid to rest in Jasper, providing closure to his family and North Central Florida community.

Buried with other unidentified remains, Christie's body was transported to the National Memorial of the Pacific in Honolulu, HI. In 2014, his family contacted the Army, thinking the unknown remains found where Christie died could potentially be connected to him.

At 18, Corporal Christie was killed while serving during the Korean War near Osan. Initially reported missing in action, the Army issued a presumptive death finding in 1953, three years after his death.

Pride is a joyous time to celebrate the diversity, resilience, and strength of our LGBTQ+ community. But it's also a time for us to put in the work.

It‚Äôs about combatting discrimination in every system that continues to treat LGBTQ+ people as second-class citizens.

The PrEP Access and Coverage Act would eliminate out-of-pocket costs for the medication, get rid of burdensome prior authorization requirements, and establish public health campaigns to increase awareness.

HIV isn't a death sentence anymore. We have medications to treat and prevent the spread of the virus. The levels of HIV in a patient‚Äôs bloodstream can become so low, it's undetectable and untransmittable.

But the stigma remains.

Rainbow Health has become a powerhouse for treating and preventing the spread of HIV and advocating for more support for those living with HIV.

Stories like the ones I heard today inspired me to write a bill to expand access to PrEP ‚Äì drugs that prevent the spread of HIV.

Rainbow Health was created by merging two organizations:

1) The Minnesota AIDS Project, which was born out of the AIDS crisis to treat patients when others would refuse.

2) The Rainbow Health Initiative, which aimed to grow our knowledge of LGBTQ+ health in Minnesota.

Pride is a time for allies to listen and learn. We need to understand the deeply rooted barriers LGBTQ+ people face in every system in our society and the lasting impacts of generations of discrimination.

I visited Rainbow Health in Minnesota to listen. Here's what I learned. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FyMeCcCWwBQ6NZi.jpg
